content: Most of the funding for HUD comes from annual appropriations by Congress to address housing problems for low-income households. Rental assistance programs like Public Housing, Section 8 Vouchers, and Section 8 project-based rental assistance make up a significant portion of HUD's funding. Block grant programs like HOME and CDBG help finance housing and community development activities for low-income families. Other specialized grant programs assist homeless individuals, including those with AIDS. HUD's programs assist homeless individuals, including those with AIDS, by providing funding through rental assistance programs and block grant programs. Surplus funds from the Federal Housing Administration have been used to offset HUD's budget costs, with additional emergency funding provided for recovery assistance after natural disasters. Table 1 shows HUD's total enacted appropriations over the past five years, with a 57% increase in regular funding in the past nine years. The growth rate has been increasing in recent years, with year-over-year increases of 5% or more each year. Adjusting for inflation, the "real" funding growth has been about 17% over the nine-year period. Most of the growth has occurred in the last two years. HUD's funding consists of various components, including regular annual appropriations, emergency appropriations, rescissions, and offsets. The majority of HUD's programs are funded through regular annual appropriations, which determine the funding for each program. Emergency appropriations are sometimes provided by Congress in response to disasters, in addition to regular annual appropriations. The cost of HUD's budget is determined by the interaction between new appropriations and offsets provided through rescissions, receipts, and collections. Net budget authority is the total amount of funding provided to HUD, including regular annual appropriations and offsets. The total net budget authority provided to HUD each year is not the best measure of funding for its programs. Despite a 57% increase in net non-emergency budget authority from FY2002 to FY2010, this increase is not solely due to increased appropriations for HUD programs. Regular annual appropriations from Congress also play a significant role in funding HUD's programs. Regular annual appropriations for HUD's programs grew by 37% from FY2002 to FY2010, mainly due to increases in Section 8 voucher and project-based rental assistance programs. Offsetting receipts and collections decreased by over 70%, and rescinded amounts dropped by 96%, contributing to the rise in net non-emergency budget authority. From FY2002 to FY2010, appropriations for Section 8 programs grew by over 70%, accounting for about 57% of HUD's regular appropriations in FY2010. Funding for other HUD programs also began to grow in FY2009 and FY2010. The decline in offsetting receipts is mainly due to decreases in receipts from FHA mortgage insurance programs. The HUD appropriations have decreased significantly from FY2004 to FY2010. The appropriations process starts with the President's budget request, followed by crafting legislation by the House and Senate Appropriations Committees. Continuing resolutions are enacted if appropriations are not completed before the fiscal year ends on September 30. The FY2011 appropriations process began in February 2010 and continued beyond the fiscal year. The FY2011 appropriations process for HUD began in February 2010 with the release of the President's budget and ended in April 2011 with the signing of P.L. 112-10 into law. The President's budget requested about $45.6 billion in net new budget authority for HUD, representing a 3% increase in appropriations for HUD programs. The President's budget requested funding increases for Section 8 programs, homeless programs, and HUD's research needs, while decreasing funding for programs for the elderly, disabled, and public housing repairs. The FY2011 HUD funding bill approved by the House would have provided about $1 billion more for HUD than requested by the President. The House and Senate bills for FY2011 HUD funding would have provided about $1 billion more than requested by the President. They rejected proposed cuts to housing programs for the elderly, disabled, public housing capital funding, and certain initiatives. The bills were not enacted before the end of the 111th Congress. The Senate bill for FY2011 HUD funding included a 1% increase in net new budget authority and a 5% increase in appropriations for HUD programs. It rejected proposed cuts to housing programs for the elderly and disabled, public housing capital funding, and the brownfields program. The bill also provided funding for the President's Transforming Rental Assistance initiative and Choice Neighborhoods Initiative. The bill was not enacted before the end of the 111th Congress, leading to a series of continuing resolutions to maintain funding at FY2010 levels. The continuing resolutions for FY2011 HUD funding extended funding through various dates, with the final CR expiring on March 4, 2011. The CR also extended FHA mortgage limit increases. A year-long CR was approved by the House on February 18, 2011, to fund the federal government through FY2011. H.R. 1 bill proposed funding cuts for HUD programs in FY2011, reducing aggregate appropriations by $5 billion (11%) compared to FY2010. The Senate failed to pass H.R. 1 or a Senate Amendment that would have increased HUD funding by nearly $6 billion. The Senate failed to pass H.R. 1 or a Senate Amendment that would have increased HUD funding by nearly $6 billion in FY2011. This would have represented a reduction of over $1 billion in net budget authority from FY2010, but an increase of about $900 million in aggregate appropriations compared to FY2010. The 112th Congress approved a short-term CR (H.J.Res. 44, P.L. 112-4) to fund the government through March 18, 2011, maintaining most accounts at FY2010 levels but reducing funding for some accounts, including the Community Development Fund for HUD. The Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) program funding was reduced under H.J.Res. 44, resulting in a $195 million decrease from FY2010 levels. This reduction eliminated funding for congressional earmarks through Economic Development Initiatives (EDI) and Neighborhood Initiatives (NI). Subsequent short-term CRs (H.J.Res. 48 and P.L. 112-8) maintained most HUD accounts at FY2010 levels but continued the funding cut for the CDF. Additionally, no funding was provided for HUD's Brownfields Redevelopment account, previously funded at $17 million in FY2010. The Department of Defense and Full-Year Continuing Appropriations Act of 2011 extended funding through April 15, 2011. It reduced funding for public housing and specified restrictions on CDF funds. The law provided year-long appropriations for the Department of Defense and other government agencies, including HUD. It funded some HUD programs at FY2010 levels, reduced funding for some programs, and increased funding for Section 8 programs. Additionally, there was an across-the-board 0.2% rescission from non-defense discretionary accounts. The law allocated an estimated $41.1 billion in net new budget authority for HUD, a decrease of about 11%. The requested decrease in net new budget authority for HUD would only represent a 4% decrease in appropriations for HUD programs in aggregate, due to an increase in offsetting collections and receipts from the FHA mortgage insurance programs. The FHA insures mortgage loans made by private lenders to eligible borrowers, who pay upfront and monthly fees for the insurance. FHA insurance helps make mortgage credit more widely available and at a lower cost. The HUD budget includes two program accounts: the Mutual Mortgage Insurance/Cooperative Management Housing Insurance Fund account (MMI/CMHI) and the General Insurance/Special Risk Insurance Fund account (GI/SRI). The MMI Fund is the largest of the FHA insurance funds, covering single-family home loans, including the Home Equity Conversion Mortgage (HECM) program. The GI/SRI Fund provides insurance for riskier home mortgages, multifamily rental housing, and special-purpose loans for hospitals and nursing homes. The Federal Credit Reform Act of 1990 (FCRA) determines the cost of federal loan insurance by calculating the net present value of expected cash flows from insured loans. Cash inflows come from insurance premiums paid by borrowers, while outflows are payments to lenders for loan defaults. The subsidy rate is the net value of these cash flows expressed as a percentage of insured loan volume. The subsidy rate is calculated based on the difference between cash inflows and outflows from insured loans. It is expressed as a negative number if cash inflows exceed outflows, and as a positive number if outflows exceed inflows. This rate is applied to the expected loan volume to determine the credit subsidy needed for federal credit programs. Agencies must adjust initial subsidy estimates based on actual loan experience. The MMI Fund historically has a negative subsidy rate. The MMI Fund historically has a negative subsidy rate, generating money for the government. It has made more in fees than paid out in claims, not needing an appropriation from Congress to operate. The Fund is divided into Purchase and Refinance risk category and HECM risk category. The Purchase and Refinance category had a negative subsidy rate of -2.59% for FY2011, higher than the -0.62% estimated for FY2010. In FY2008, Congress allocated funding for foreclosure mitigation counseling to NeighborWorks America, not HUD. This funding became the National Foreclosure Mitigation Counseling Program (NFMCP). NeighborWorks is an independent nonprofit corporation that usually receives its own annual appropriation from Congress for community reinvestment activities. NeighborWorks America received $180 million in funding for mortgage foreclosure counseling activities through the National Foreclosure Mitigation Counseling Program (NFMCP) in 2008. Subsequent appropriations have been lower, with the President's budget requesting $113 million in FY2011. H.R. 5850 and S. 3644 included $113 million and $125 million for the NFMCP, respectively, with S. 3644 also allocating $24 million more for housing activities than the House-passed bill or the President's budget. The final FY2011 appropriations law (P.L. 112-10) maintained funding for the NFMCP at $65 million, with housing counseling agencies supporting foreclosure prevention initiatives like HAMP. Recipients of NFMCP funding can use up to 30% of their grants to counsel borrowers with high debt-to-income ratios eligible for HAMP. Native American Housing Block Grants (NAHBGs) are formula-based grants for Indian tribes to provide housing assistance primarily to low-income American Indian and Alaskan Native households. In FY2010, Congress provided $700 million for the NAHBG account, with set-asides for technical assistance and loan guarantees. In FY2010, $4.25 million was allocated for general technical assistance, $3.5 million for the National American Indian Housing Council (NAIHC) for training, and $2 million for loan guarantees. The President's FY2011 budget requested $580 million for Native American Housing Block Grants, a decrease of $120 million from FY2010. H.R. 1 proposed $500 million for NAHBG, $200 million less than FY2010. The final FY2011 appropriations law (P.L. 112-10) provided nearly $650 million to this account, over $50 million below the FY2010 enacted level but nearly $70 million higher than the President's FY2011 budget request. The enacted FY2011 appropriations law also maintained the set-asides within this account at FY2010 levels, less the 0.2% across-the-board rescission. The annual budget resolution acts as an agreement between the House and Senate establishing parameters within which Congress can consider legislation dealing with spending and revenue. The House and Senate budget committees divide their allocation among 12 subcommittees responsible for appropriations bills. They receive input from various sources to formulate the budget resolution, with a target completion date of April 15. The Senate Budget Committee reported a budget resolution for FY2011, but no further action was taken. The House Budget Committee did not report a resolution, leading to different proceedings in the House and Senate. The House and Senate proceeded differently in the absence of a budget resolution. The House adopted a budget enforcement resolution, while the Senate did not agree to enforceable spending allocations.
